review.title: Detection and Resolution of Rumours in Social Media: A Survey
review.abstract: Despite the increasing use of social media platforms for information and news gathering, its unmoderated nature often leads to the emergence and spread of rumours, i.e. pieces of information that are unverified at the time of posting. At the same time, the openness of social media platforms provides opportunities to study how users share and discuss rumours, and to explore how natural language processing and data mining techniques may be used to find ways of determining their veracity. In this survey we introduce and discuss two types of rumours that circulate on social media; long-standing rumours that circulate for long periods of time, and newly-emerging rumours spawned during fast-paced events such as breaking news, where reports are released piecemeal and often with an unverified status in their early stages. We provide an overview of research into social media rumours with the ultimate goal of developing a rumour classification system that consists of four components: rumour detection, rumour tracking, rumour stance classification and rumour veracity classification. We delve into the approaches presented in the scientific literature for the development of each of these four components. We summarise the efforts and achievements so far towards the development of rumour classification systems and conclude with suggestions for avenues for future research in social media mining for detection and resolution of rumours.

sections.heading: 6.1. Definition of the Task and Evaluation
sections.text: The task of detecting rumors is that a system must determine, based on a series of social media posts, which messages spread rumors and thus spread information that has yet to be verified. Note that the fact that a tweet is a rumor does not imply that it is later considered true or false, but that it is not verified at the time of publication. Formally, the task considers a timeframe of social media posts TL = {t1,..., t | TL |} as input, and the classifier must determine whether each of these posts, ti, is a rumor or or a non-rumor by assigning a label of Y = {R, NR}. Thus, the task is usually formulated as a binary classification problem whose performance is evaluated by calculating the accuracy, recall, and F1 values for the target category, i.e. rumors.

sections.heading: 6.2. Datasets
sections.text: The only publicly available data set is the PHEME data set of rumors and non-rumors [Zubiaga et al. 2016b], which contains a collection of 1,972 rumors and 3,830 non-rumors associated with five breaking news.

sections.heading: 6.3. Approaches to Rumour Detection
sections.text: Despite the growing interest in analyzing rumors on social media and building tools to deal with rumors that had not previously been identified [Seo et al. 2012; Takahashi and Igata 2012], there was very little work in automatically detecting rumors. Some of the tweets in the detection of rumors [Qazvinian et al. 2011; Hamidian and Diab 2015; 2016] were limited to finding rumors based on predefined rumors (e.g. Obama is Muslim) that classify new tweets as related to one of the known rumors (e.g., I think Obama is not Muslim informed about the rumor, while Obama was talking to a group of Muslims who should not be monitored). An approach like this can be useful for long-standing rumors where one wants to identify relevant tweets to track the rumors that have already been identified; in this survey, we refer to this task as rumor tracking because one is aware of the rumors that are being monitored.

sections.heading: 7.1. Definition of the Task and Evaluation
sections.text: The Rumor Tracker component is triggered as soon as a rumor is detected, and consists of identifying subsequent posts related to the rumor to be monitored. Input typically consists of a stream of posts that can be tailored to the rumor after filtering by relevant keywords, or it can be expanded by including posts related to a major event or even an unlimited stream of posts. Generally, the task is defined as a binary classification task, which is to determine whether or not each of the posts is related to the rumor. Output will be a labeled version of the posting stream, in which labels define whether or not each post is related. Traditional binary classification evaluation methods are used for this task, namely precision, recall, and F1 score, where the positive class is the number of related posts.

sections.heading: 7.2. Datasets
sections.text: The most commonly used rumor tracking data set is that of [Qazvinian et al. 2011], which includes over 10,000 tweets associated with 5 different rumors, with each tweet being commented as related or unrelated due to its relevance to the rumor. Unrelated tweets have similar characteristics to related ones, such as overlapping keywords, making classification more difficult. Although not specifically intended for rumor tracking, the [Zubiaga et al. 2016] data set provides over 4,500 tweets categorized by rumor. This data set differs in that it does not contain tweets with similar characteristics that are actually unrelated. Instead, it provides tweets associated with various rumor and tweets grouped by rumor.

sections.heading: 7.3. Approaches to Rumour Tracking
sections.text: Despite the early work of [Qazvinian et al. 2011], which performs automated rumor tracking, few studies have subsequently followed their research line when it comes to determining the relevance of tweets to rumor. [Qazvinian et al. 2011] use a manually generated Twitter dataset of 10K tweets to derive a supervised machine learning approach. Authors use various functions categorized as "content," "network" and "Twitter-specific memes." However, the content category contains unigrams, bigrams and their part of speech (POS) tags as characteristics. In the network category, authors consider retweets (RT) as a feature. Finally, Twitter-specific memes include content characteristics derived from hashtags and URLs. A Bayesian classifier is used as a machine learning approach. The best performance was achieved by using content-based characteristics, with an average accuracy of 6.5% in 2015 and higher, with an average accuracy of 9% in 2011.

sections.heading: 11. DISCUSSION: SUMMARY AND FUTURE RESEARCH DIRECTIONS
sections.text: Research into the development of tools for detecting and verifying rumors is growing in popularity as the proliferation of rumors on social media has increased, enabling both ordinary users and professional users to collect news and facts in real time, but with the problematic side-effect of disseminating information of an unconfirmed nature. This survey summarizes studies reported in the scientific literature on the development of classification systems for rumors, defines and characterizes rumors in social media and describes the different approaches to the development of its four main components: (1) detection of rumors, (2) rumor tracking, (3) classification of rumors, and (4) classification of rumors. In this way, the survey provides a state-of-the-art guide to the development of these components. Below, we review the progress made so far, the deficiencies of existing systems, outline proposals for future research, and comment on the applicability and generalizability of rumors as more widely available in social media, as well as in social media.

sections.heading: 11.1. Open Challenges and Future Research Directions
sections.text: In recent years, odor classification research has largely focused on the later stages of the pipeline, namely the classification of rumors and the truthfulness of the classification. These are critical stages, but they cannot be used to detect rumors and tracking posts related to these rumors without performing the previous tasks, which have been skipped in the past by focusing either on detecting rumors and tracking rumors. An important limitation in the development of odor classification systems has been made by a human.

sections.heading: 11.2. Rumours, Hoaxes, Misinformation, Disinformation, Fake News
sections.text: As defined in Section 1.1, rumors refer to portions of information that begin with unconfirmed statements; the truth value of a rumor cannot be verified at an early stage, but is subsequently resolved as true or false within a relatively short period of time, or may remain unconfirmed for a long time; a number of similar terms are also used in related literature that have different characteristics but also similarities with rumors; the term misinformation is used to refer to the dissemination of information that is false as a result of an honest mistake, while disinformation refers to information that is intentionally false [Hernon 1995]. Rumors can fall into either of these two categories, depending on the intent of the source; however, the main difference is that rumors are not necessarily false but turn out to be false.

sections.heading: 11.3. Further Reading
sections.text: For further discussion of the topics covered in this survey, we recommend the special issue on trust and truthfulness of information on social media of ACM TOIS [Papadopoulos et al. 2016; Rijke 2016], Full Fact's report on the state of automated fact-checking [Babakar and Moy 2016], reports and discussions on rumors on Snopes30 and Craig Silverman's books on rumors and journalistic verification practices [Silverman 2013; 2015a; 2015b]. metadata.abstractText: Despite the increasing use of social media platforms for information and news gathering, its unmoderated nature often leads to the emergence and spread of rumours, i.e. pieces of information that are unverified at the time of posting. At the same time, the openness of social media platforms provides opportunities to study how users share and discuss rumours, and to explore how natural language processing and data mining techniques may be used to find ways of determining their veracity. In this survey we introduce and discuss two types of rumours that circulate on social media; long-standing rumours that circulate for long periods of time, and newly-emerging rumours spawned during fast-paced events such as breaking news, where reports are released piecemeal and often with an unverified status in their early stages. We provide an overview of research into social media rumours with the ultimate goal of developing a rumour classification system that consists of four components: rumour detection, rumour tracking, rumour stance classification and rumour veracity classification. We delve into the approaches presented in the scientific literature for the development of each of these four components. We summarise the efforts and achievements so far towards the development of rumour classification systems and conclude with suggestions for avenues for future research in social media mining for detection and resolution of rumours.
